key_title: Key to the species of Fumaria

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Papaveraceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Fumariaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Fumariaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Corolla 9 mm long or more; largest leaf-segments often 2 mm wide or more
Corolla less than 9 mm long; largest leaf-segments often less than 2 mm wide
Flower predominantly pink; sepals less than 4 mm long; fruiting pedicels erect or arcuate, not strongly reflexed
Flower predominantly white (rarely flushed red); sepals 4 mm long or more; fruiting pedicels strongly recurved

Inner petals with pale yellow median streak (becoming more prominent on drying), lower petal wider than 0.5 mm medially; peduncles and pedicels rather stout, pedicels remaining erect in fruit; fruit rather straight-sided, squarish at base, distinctly tuberculate-rugulose at maturity

Inner petals lacking median yellow streak, lower petal less than 0.5 mm wide medially; peduncles and pedicels slender, pedicels commonly arcuate and spreading in fruit; fruit rounded, smooth to minutely tuberculate
Sepals less than 1.5 mm (usually less than 1 mm) long; bracts exceeding flowering pedicels
Flowers pink; largest leaf-segments wider than 0.5 mm
Flowers white (sometimes becoming flushed red after fertilization); largest leaf-segments to c. 0.5 mm broad
Sepals ovate, narrower than corolla; bracts shorter than to equal to flowering pedicels
Sepals broadly ovate to subrotund, broader than corolla; bracts exceeding flowering pedicels
Inner petals with median yellow streak; pedicels remaining erect in fruit; fruit rather straight-sided, squarish at base, distinctly tuberculate-rugulose
Inner petals rarely with median yellow streak; pedicels commonly arcuate and spreading in fruit; fruit rounded, smooth to minutely tuberculate
